articles.headline: Automakers Delay Electric Vehicle Spending as Demand Slows
articles.snippet: Growth is brisk but slower than expected, causing automakers to question their multibillion-dollar investments in new factories and raising doubts about the effectiveness of federal incentives.
articles.abstract: Growth is brisk but slower than expected, causing automakers to question their multibillion-dollar investments in new factories and raising doubts about the effectiveness of federal incentives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Normally a 50 percent increase in sales is considered very good. But when the number of electric vehicles sold in the United States grew that much during the third quarter from a year earlier, it was a disappointment.

articles.headline: ‘Morning in America’ Eludes Biden, Despite Economic Gains
articles.snippet: Seeking re-election in 1984, Ronald Reagan presided over an economy similar in many ways to today’s. But he sold a message of progress and promise.
articles.abstract: Seeking re-election in 1984, Ronald Reagan presided over an economy similar in many ways to today’s. But he sold a message of progress and promise.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Ronald Reagan rode a “Morning in America” message to a blowout re-election victory in 1984, based partly on warm feelings about his economic performance. Today’s economy is similar in many ways to Mr. Reagan’s as he entered that campaign, with one big difference: There is widespread voter angst over the incumbent’s economic stewardship.

articles.headline: Ohio Vote Continues a Winning Streak for Abortion Rights
articles.snippet: The State Constitution will protect access to the procedure. The ballot result sends a strong signal that voters are still angry about the demise of Roe.
articles.abstract: The State Constitution will protect access to the procedure. The ballot result sends a strong signal that voters are still angry about the demise of Roe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ohio’s resounding approval of a ballot measure enshrining a right to abortion in the State Constitution continued a winning streak for abortion-rights groups that have appealed directly to voters after the demise of Roe v. Wade.

articles.headline: Mark Zuckerberg Taps the Strengths of WhatsApp
articles.snippet: The messaging app, which Meta bought nearly a decade ago, was an asset that Mr. Zuckerberg largely left alone for a while. No longer.
articles.abstract: The messaging app, which Meta bought nearly a decade ago, was an asset that Mr. Zuckerberg largely left alone for a while. No longer.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Facebook bought WhatsApp for $19 billion nearly a decade ago, Mark Zuckerberg made a promise: The Facebook chief said he wouldn’t meddle often with the messaging app so as not to mess with a good thing.

articles.headline: ‘If Not Me, Who?’: As Ukraine Seeks Troops, Women Prepare for the Call
articles.snippet: With so much in the war against Russia hinging on refilling the ranks of soldiers, efforts are underway to draw more Ukrainian women into the army.
articles.abstract: With so much in the war against Russia hinging on refilling the ranks of soldiers, efforts are underway to draw more Ukrainian women into the army.
articles.lead_paragraph: Halyna Vynokur, a clerk in a hardware store in Kyiv, was shouldering a firearm for the first time. Iryna Sychova, a purchasing manager at a department store, disassembled and reassembled the jumble of rods and springs in a Kalashnikov rifle.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova

articles.headline: A New Law Supercharged Electric Car Manufacturing, but Not Sales
articles.snippet: President Biden’s 2022 climate act spurred big investments in U.S. battery factories, but it has not similarly boosted E.V. sales.
articles.abstract: President Biden’s 2022 climate act spurred big investments in U.S. battery factories, but it has not similarly boosted E.V. sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden’s signature climate law has stimulated a surge of investment in electric vehicle production across the country, including tens of billions of dollars on battery plants across the South and new assembly lines near the Great Lakes. Based on early evidence, it is succeeding at a goal that economists have long considered difficult and costly: using the power of government to rapidly grow a new industry.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley, Ana Swanson, Jack Ewing and Coral Davenport

articles.headline: Behind Hamas’s Bloody Gambit to Create a ‘Permanent’ State of War
articles.snippet: Hamas leaders say they waged their Oct. 7 attack on Israel because they believed the Palestinian cause was slipping away, and that only violence could revive it.
articles.abstract: Hamas leaders say they waged their Oct. 7 attack on Israel because they believed the Palestinian cause was slipping away, and that only violence could revive it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thousands have been killed in Gaza, with entire families wiped out. Israeli airstrikes have reduced Palestinian neighborhoods to expanses of rubble, while doctors treat screaming children in darkened hospitals with no anesthesia. Across the Middle East, fear has spread over the possible outbreak of a broader regional war.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and Maria Abi-Habib

articles.headline: The End of Panda Diplomacy?
articles.snippet: The giant pandas have left Washington. Some fans find it unbearable.
articles.abstract: The giant pandas have left Washington. Some fans find it unbearable.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Erin Schaff

articles.headline: Google’s Open Culture Collides With the Israel-Hamas War
articles.snippet: Google has long been a hub for employee activism, including over the company’s business with Israel. But workers looking to express support for Palestinians say they face hostility.
articles.abstract: Google has long been a hub for employee activism, including over the company’s business with Israel. But workers looking to express support for Palestinians say they face hostility.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Sarmad Gilani joined Google as a software engineer in 2012, he was drawn by the company’s famously open culture, where employees can publicly criticize leadership and are encouraged to embrace their racial identity and sexual orientation while at work.
articles.byline: By Santul Nerkar and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Does the Boss Need to Weigh In on the War in the Middle East?
articles.snippet: It’s become the norm for company executives to issue notes to employees about social upheaval. But the Israel-Hamas war presents a special challenge.
articles.abstract: It’s become the norm for company executives to issue notes to employees about social upheaval. But the Israel-Hamas war presents a special challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: After reading the details of Hamas’s attacks on Israel on Oct. 7, Brad Karp, who runs the law firm Paul, Weiss, sat at his computer and wrote a memo to his roughly 2,000 employees.
